text: Bottle in Seattle. Thanks prufrockstar. Lingering tan cream, heavy brown body. Sweet chocolate nose. Lovely dry body, chocolate sweet roast. Thin caramel. Lots of coffee, light lactic depth. More sweet booze on nose than sip. Lovely, tasty beer. Some minty and crisp on finish. Nice, tasty beer.
Bottle shared by a friend. Pours black with a thin off-white head. Aroma of malt, creamy vanilla and chocolate. Chocolate and vanilla flavor with a creamy finish.

12oz bottle from an unknown trade. Pours black with a half finger of creamy light tan head. Aroma of mostly milk chocolate and Irish cream. Taste of black malts, earth, light chocolate, and hints of Irish cream. Thin mouthfeel. Meh

Sample at The J Bar as part of Ohio Brew Week. Brown-black color with a medium beige head that diminishes gradually to a film. Patchy lacing on the glass. Aroma of chocolate, Irish creme and malt. Light to medium body with flavors roast malt, chocolate and Irish creme. The finish is sweet with a Baileys-like aftertaste. Pretty good all around.
Bottle. Irish cream, chocolate malt, and light ash aroma. Dark brown with large tan head. Sweet Irish cream, chocolate malt, and moderately bitter herbal hay flavor. Good body. Delicious.

On tap at Firehouse Grill, arrived in a shaker pint.

Appearance: As expected for a stout, this arrived in the glass an impenetrable black, capped with a fairly thick tan head that lasted a while. Lacing was decent as I drank it down.

Smell: Unfortunately, this place had a kitchen, which always makes discerning aroma interesting. Fortunately, I was a fair distance from said kitchen, so I was able to do so. This beer smells sweet as can be, as though some burnt bread had been dunked in refined molasses and then slathered with marshmallow creme. Rather inviting stuff!

Taste: The smell didnt lie. This stout opens as a mouthful of dry, blackened grain and dark bread, much like a dry Irish stout, before the rush of other flavors surges in. Sweetness abruptly skyrockets, brought in by what seems like a mix of toffee syrup and lactose. Butterscotch notes mingle with hints of vanilla, and the Irish creme is definitely present in spades, mixing with the other flavor notes to form something not unlike marshmallow. Definitely a tasty beer.

Mouthfeel: Medium to full bodied with a decent level of carbonation, this drinks stouty.

Overall: Im a fan. But given that this is from Listermann / Triple Digit, that almost goes without saying. Ill repeat this one any time they choose to brew it.

Bottle:
Pours black, with a thick tan head.
Milk chocolate, Irish cream aroma.
Creamy, sweet chocolate malt, lightly minty flavour.
Very rich....smooth and silky.
Wonderful tasting stuff.
On tap at Jungle Jim. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Slightly sweet aroma. Taste the same with some chocolate flavors. Light palate. Decent lacing. Nothing special.

Draft pour. The beer is a dark brown with a creamy head of beige foam. The beer. It really has that minty chocolate irish cream thing nailed. Shit. Pretty sweet and irish creamy. Nice, and very different.

Draft at St Patricks day event at Dutchs 2013 notes. Pours dark brown in color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma and flavor have a nice amount of roasted malt, chocolate, sweetness from the Irish cream, smooth, easy drinking local stout.

Draft at the brewery. Pours a deep brown with a moderate creamy tan head. Aroma of Irish Creme, milk chocolate, nuts, dust, leaves, and brown sugar. Flavor of chocolate, cream, nuts, leaves, mild roast. Light-bodied, with a dry, almost chalky mouthfeel and soft moderate carbonation. Very smooth and dry with some sweetness. Pretty good. Really easy drinking.

Tap. Poured a black color with an average fizzy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy sweet lactic aroma. Medium to heavy sweet chocolate flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration. Full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. This is a good rich beer.

On tap. Dark brown color. Thin light brown head, leaves lots of dotty lace. Definite irish creme aroma, very nice. Medium body. Light carbonation. Smooth, more creamy texture. Good sweeter taste, light bitter. Toasty malts, some milk chocolate. Unique irish stout, with that irish creme.

Draft to plastic pint glass at Dutchs St. Paddys day party. Looks good; a dark cola with beige lacing. Smells and tastes solid; malty, but delightfully smooth (from the Irish Creme). Nice on the palate. Good beer.
